Herbs Overview.Properties: Varies per herb, including immune support, detoxification, cognitive function enhancement, energy boosting, and more.
Herbs Overview.Uses: Range from treating indigestion, IBS, constipation, diarrhea, acid reflux, liver health support, appetite control, food allergies, stress relief, anxiety and depression management, enhancing mental clarity, sleep aids, mood boosting, ADHD, cognitive function, emotional balance, memory enhancement, pain relief, joint health, heart health, weight management, skin health, eye health, bone health, to physical performance enhancement.
Herbs Overview.Preparation methods: Includes teas, extracts, capsules, topical applications, and dietary inclusion.
Herbs Overview.Cautions: Specific cautions vary per herb; general caution advised for self-diagnosing and treating without professional guidance. Adherence to laws and regulations, and consultation with a healthcare provider recommended.

Herbal Collection Storage.Uses: Proper storage is crucial for preserving potency and extending shelf life of herbs.
Herbal Collection Storage.Preparation Methods: Store dried herbs in dark glass jars or opaque containers to block light. Keep in cool, dry place away from direct sunlight and humidity. Store tinctures and oils in dark glass bottles in cool, dark places. Infused oils should be refrigerated. Salves and creams should also be kept in cool, dry conditions.
Herbal Collection Storage.Cautions: Avoid light, heat, and moisture. Regularly check for signs of spoilage such as discoloration, loss of fragrance, or mold. Discard any spoiled preparations.

Herbal Capsules.Uses: Used for easy consumption and dosage of powdered herbs.
Herbal Capsules.Preparation Methods: Use a capsule machine and empty vegetable capsules to fill with powdered herbs.
Herbal Capsules.Cautions: Ensure powdered herbs are stored properly before capsule preparation to maintain potency.

Herbal Teas and Loose Blends.Preparation Methods: Use tea infusers or muslin bags for steeping herbs without mess.

Tinctures.Preparation Methods: Store in dark glass bottles in cool, dark places.
Tinctures.Cautions: A change in smell or cloudiness may indicate contamination.

Infused Oils.Uses: Shorter shelf life than tinctures, used for various medicinal purposes.
Infused Oils.Preparation Methods: Should be stored in the refrigerator to extend shelf life.
Infused Oils.Cautions: More susceptible to rancidity. Discard if off smell develops or if separated.

Salves and Creams.Cautions: Use within 6-12 months. Discard if an off smell develops or if separated.

Preparation methods.Calming Tea: Combine 1 tablespoon dried motherwort with 1 tablespoon dried lemon balm in 2 cups hot water, steep for 10-15 minutes, strain, and enjoy before bedtime.

Preparation methods.Heart Tonic: Steep 1 tablespoon hawthorn berries and 1 tablespoon hibiscus flowers in 2 cups hot water for 15 minutes, strain, and serve warm.
